questions.question: A biker met with an accident and sustained a maxillofacial injury. Which of the following isthe first step in the primary care of this patient?
Which of the following facial bones is most commonly fractured?
questions.explanation: The most commonly fractured bone of the face is the nasal bone because of the projection of thenose on the face.

questions.question: A 30-year-old man presented with a nasal bleed after sustaining a blow to the nose in a fistfight. On evaluation, a nasal septal fracture similar to the one in the image below was identified. What is your diagnosis?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario of nasal bleed following trauma and the image showing a horizontal fracture line is suggestive of Jarjaw fracture. It is a fracture of the nasal septum that results from direct blows from the front. The fracture line runs horizontally from just above the anterior nasal spine to just above the junction of septal cartilage with vomer. Option C: Chevallet fracture results from blows from below. The fracture line runs vertically from the anterior nasal spine upwards to the junction of the bony and cartilaginous dorsum of the nose. Option D: Tripod fracture is another name for zygoma fracture.

questions.question: A young adult presents with a deformed nose after falling from a ladder. The CT scan shows adisplaced nasal fracture. What is the ideal time to reduce the fracture in this patient?
questions.explanation: The ideal time for reduction of fracture of the nasal bone is 5-7 days following injury, once theedema has subsided.The presence of edema interferes with the accurate reduction of the fracture. In most cases, thedeformity is due to edema. So, ice packs and head elevation are advised initially after injury. After3-5 days, the edema would subside and the underlying deformity will be apparent on clinicalassessment.After 2 weeks it is difficult to reduce since the process of callus formation and the bony andfibrous union would have started.

questions.question: As an ENT resident, you are assisting in the reduction of a nasal bone fracture. Which of the following instruments would you use?
questions.explanation: Walsham forceps is used to reduce a nasal bone fracture. Asch forceps is mainly used to reduce nasal septum fracture. Walsham forceps is the correct choice. Option A: Luc's forceps is used in Caldwell Luc operation, submucous resection, and polypectomy. Option C: Tilley's forceps is used in nasal packing in epistaxis. Option D: Citelli's forceps is used for bone punch.

questions.question: A boxer is wheeled into the ER with complaints of seeing double after having suffered a severe blow to his face during a match. On examination, there is a flattening of malar prominence, trismus, and a step deformity of the infraorbital margin. What is the likely diagnosis?
questions.explanation:
The given clinical scenario of diplopia, flat malar prominence, trismus, and step deformity in the infraorbital margin is suggestive of a fracture of zygoma or tripod fracture. Zygoma is the second most frequently fractured bone in the face. The zygoma fracture is separated at its three processes - the zygomaticofrontal suture, infraorbital margin, and the zygomaticotemporal suture. It has the following clinical features: 
   • Flattening of malar prominence.
   • Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.
   • Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve.
   • Step deformity of infraorbital margin.
   • Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of the lateral palpebral ligament.
   • Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of the inferior rectus muscle. It may cause diplopia.
   • Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.

questions.explanation: CSF rhinorrhea is not seen in patients with fractures of the zygoma.It has the following clinical features:• Flattening of malar prominence.•Step deformity of infraorbital margin.• Anesthesia in the distribution of the infraorbital nerve.• Trismus, due to depression of zygoma on the underlying coronoid process.•Oblique palpebral fissure, due to the displacement of lateral palpebral ligament.• Restricted ocular movements, due to entrapment of inferior rectus muscle. It may causediplopia.• Periorbital emphysema, due to escape of air from the maxillary sinus on nose blowing.The following x-ray shows a right-sided zygoma fracture:397

questions.question: A patient with a tripod fracture is having decreased sensation over the cheek. Which of thefollowing nerve injuries can result in this?
questions.explanation: Infraorbital nerve injury results in decreased sensation over the cheek in tripod(zygomatic)fracture.

questions.question: A 19-year-old college student presented with complaints of seeing double after sustaining ablow to his face in a scuffle with his seniors. On examination, there is a step deformity andperiorbital emphysema. Entrapment of which of the following muscles is likely to beresponsible for his double vision?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario with diplopia, periorbital emphysema, and a step deformity can beseen in both orbital floor fracture as well as tripod fracture. In both conditions diplopia is due to:• Entrapment of inferior rectus and inferior oblique muscles•Displacement of the eyeball.The common features seen in both orbital floor fracture and tripod fracture are:•Periorbital emphysema•Step deformity of infraorbital margin• Diplopia•Enophthalmos.

questions.question: In which of the following fractures Le-Fort classification is used?
questions.explanation: Le-Fort classification is used in the fracture of the maxilla.The 3 types are:•Le Fort I (transverse fracture)• Le Fort II (pyramidal fracture)• Le Fort III (craniofacial disjunction).

questions.question: Which of the following bones is not involved in Le-Fort fractures?
questions.explanation: 399The mandible is not involved in Le-Fort's fractures.

questions.question: The CT scan of a patient who met with a motorcycle accident shows a fracture of the maxilla. The fracture line passes through the floor of the nose, separating the palate from the rest of the face. How will you classify the fracture?
questions.explanation: The CT findings describe a Le-Fort I fracture of the maxilla. It is also known as Guerin's fracture.

questions.question: Which of the following is the most common site for fracture of the mandible in children?
questions.explanation: The most common site of fracture of the mandible in children is the condyle. It is because thecondylar head is connected to the vertical ramus of the bone by a thin neck which gives awayeasily to an impact.Mandibular fractures:Children:• Due to falls and sports injuries.•• Most common site - condyle.Adults > 50 years:• Most commonly due to falls.• Most common site - body (the molar area is the weakest area in an edentulous mandible).Young Adults:•• Due to falls, assaults, and accidents.• The site of fracture depends on the nature of impact and the direction of force applied.

questions.question: A 23-year-old college student presented with jaw pain and trismus after falling from a bike. A diagnosis of mandibular fracture was made. Which of the following classifications is used for this?
questions.explanation: Dingman's classification is used in the classification of fractures of the mandible. Dingman's classification is based on the region in which the fracture is located. The seven regions used in this classification are as shown below: Dingman and Natvig classification of mandibular fractures - Condylar, Ramus, Coronoid, Angular, Body-Alveolar-Symphyseal. Option A: Le-Fort classification is used in maxillary fractures. Option C: Gartland classification is used in supracondylar fractures of the humerus. Option D: Pauwel classification is used in the neck of femur fractures.

questions.question: Following trauma, a patient presented with clear watery nasal discharge that cannot besniffed back. Fractures of which of the following bones is the most likely cause for this?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea and fracture of the cribriform plate ofthe ethmoid is the most common cause for this.Causes of CSF rhinorrhea:• Trauma (accidental or surgical) - most of the cases follow trauma. Surgical trauma includesendoscopic sinus surgery, trans-sphenoidal hypophysectomy, nasal polypectomy, or skull basesurgery.• Inflammations - mucoceles of sinuses, sinonasal polyposis, the fungal infection of sinuses andosteomyelitis, can all erode the bone and dura.••Neoplasms tumours, both benign and malignant, invading the skull base.Congenital lesions - meningocele, meningoencephaloceles, and gliomas can have associated skullbase defects.• Idiopathic - where the cause is unknown and the patient has a spontaneous leak.

questions.question: Which of the following fractures is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea?
questions.explanation: Le-Fort I fracture is not associated with CSF rhinorrhea. Whereas, fractures like Le-Fort II, IIIand naso-orbito-ethmoid fracture are associated with CSF rhinorrhea.401

questions.question: A middle-aged woman, who had undergone a polypectomy complains of watery nasaldischarge on bending forward. Which of the following is false regarding this condition?
questions.explanation: The given clinical scenario is suggestive of CSF rhinorrhea secondary to surgery.Identifying features of CSF Rhinorrhea:1. The CSF discharge is thin, watery, and clear in appearance.2. It cannot be sniffed back. (Option D)3. It does not stiffen a handkerchief.4. It shows positional variation: The watery CSF discharge occurs suddenly and gushes in dropsonly on bending the head forward/straining.5. The Halo sign is a marker of CSF rhinorrhea post-head trauma. It is considered positive when aclear ring surrounds a central bloody spot after the discharge is dropped on a handkerchief/papertowel.6. Reservoir sign: The discharge is seen on rising in the morning and bending the head, as fluidaccumulated in the sinuses empties into the nose.

questions.question: In a patient with suspected CSF rhinorrhea, the presence of which of the following in the nasal discharge will confirm the diagnosis?
questions.explanation: Presence of β 2 transferrin protein in the nasal discharge confirms the presence of CSF in the specimen. β 2 transferrin protein detection by electrophoresis is a sensitive and specific test for CSF. It is secreted by meninges and choroid plexus. Since it is absent in nasal secretions, it helps to differentiate CSF from nasal secretions. It is also present in aqueous humor and perilymph. Another method is glucose testing by oxidase peroxidase or biochemical estimation. CSF glucose is 60% of blood glucose, whereas it is <10mg/dl in nasal secretions. It is not reliable in associated meningitis (reduced levels giving false-negative results) and when CSF is mixed with blood.

questions.question: What is the preferred line of management in a patient with CSF rhinorrhea who is otherwise stable?
questions.explanation: Patients with CSF rhinorrhea who are stable are managed conservatively. The conservative measures are: • Bed rest • Elevation of the head end • Stool softeners • Avoidance of nose-blowing, sneezing, and straining. Prophylactic antibiotics can be used to prevent meningitis, and acetazolamide to decrease CSF formation. Surgery is done if the conservative management fails.
